word.entryDescription: moving pictures and sound, often telling a story
word.entryExample: I saw a great film at the weekend.

word.entryDescription: a large paper picture or notice that advertises a film
word.entryExample: Those scary film posters were everywhere!

word.entryDescription: a famous film actor
word.entryExample: I just can't stop thinking about getting married to my boyfriend when the film stars kiss.

word.entryDescription: to pass something through a device to remove parts of it
word.entryExample: If you can, it's better to drink mineral water or water that has been filtered.

word.entryDescription: the last game, race, etc in a series, the winner of which becomes champion of the competition
word.entryExample: Rachel and Lucy were in the talent show final but didn't win.

word.entryDescription: after a long time; in the end
word.entryExample: Finally, put the pizza in the oven for about 20 minutes.

word.entryDescription: the matter of money, its supply and its management
word.entryExample: Her dad predicts that she won't work in finance.

word.entryDescription: to see something after looking for it
word.entryExample: Where's my doll? I can't find it.

word.entryDescription: to get information
word.entryExample: I want to find out the answer.

word.entryDescription: good enough or feeling well without any problems
word.entryExample: My sister's fine now, thank you.

word.entryDescription: money that you have to pay as punishment for something
word.entryExample: He had been driving too fast and was given a large fine.

word.entryDescription: a long thin part of the body on your hand
word.entryExample: I tried to open a tin of beans but my fingers really hurt.

word.entryDescription: a mark left on something by somebody's finger that shows a unique pattern of curved lines and which can be used to identify that person
word.entryExample: Fingerprints are also a unique way of identifying people.

word.entryDescription: to come to the end of
word.entryExample: The lesson finishes at 2 o'clock.

word.entryDescription: an area where you burn paper or wood
word.entryExample: You mustn't make a fire in the forest.

word.entryDescription: the vehicle that firefighters use for driving and carrying equipment to put out fires
word.entryExample: I heard a fire engine siren. There must be a fire somewhere nearby.

word.entryDescription: somebody whose job is to stop fires
word.entryExample: My dad is a fire fighter.

word.entryDescription: the building in which the fire brigade is based
word.entryExample: My father works at the fire station.

word.entryDescription: somebody whose job is to stop fires
word.entryExample: Sam wants to be a fireman when he grows up.

word.entryDescription: in the position of number one when we count
word.entryExample: This is my first time in Ireland.

word.entryDescription: basic treatment given to somebody soon after they have become injured or ill
word.entryExample: Red Cross trains people in first aid skills to help save lives in their local communities.

word.entryDescription: a type of sentence used to express that the action in the main clause can only take place if certain condition is fulfilled.
word.entryExample: Does the test tomorrow cover the first conditional or is it only past tenses?

word.entryDescription: used to introduce the first of a number of things that you want to say; firstly
word.entryExample: First of all, she woke up late and missed her bus.

word.entryDescription: used to introduce the first of a number of things that you want to say; first of all
word.entryExample: Firstly, we can save energy by turning off electrical appliances at the wall instead of leaving them on standby.

word.entryDescription: an animal that lives in the sea, lake, etc, with a tail; or the flesh of this animal that we can eat
word.entryExample: There are a lot of fish in the sea.

word.entryDescription: somebody who catches fish for a living
word.entryExample: The fisherman's boat is on the beach.

word.entryDescription: to be the right shape or size for
word.entryExample: I'm afraid these shoes don't fit me. Have you got a larger size?

word.entryDescription: physically healthy and strong
word.entryExample: Try to exercise every day to keep fit.

word.entryDescription: the health and strength of the body
word.entryExample: Team sports are great fun and help improve your health and fitness.

word.entryDescription: comparative of 'fit' – physically healthy and strong
word.entryExample: You will soon be a lot fitter than before.

word.entryDescription: a room in a clothes shop where you can try clothes on before you buy them
word.entryExample: Why don't you try them on? The fitting rooms are over there.

word.entryDescription: the number 5
word.entryExample: My brother is five years old.

word.entryDescription: a piece of cloth with a pattern or picture on it which represents a country or group
word.entryExample: The flag starts to fly in the Olympic stadium at the start of the opening ceremony.

word.entryDescription: the burning gas that you see coming from a fire
word.entryExample: The flame in Olympic torches is carried by relay runners to the Olympic stadium.

word.entryDescription: becoming wider at one end
word.entryExample: Flared jeans are back in fashion nowadays.

word.entryDescription: a short bright light
word.entryExample: When Steve shows us the flash, this is the ignition working.

word.entryDescription: a bread made with flour, water and salt and rolled into a flat dough
word.entryExample: Would you like some flatbread with your soup?

word.entryDescription: someone who you share a flat with
word.entryExample: Jack is the flatmate whose university course lasts for four years.

word.entryDescription: the way food tastes
word.entryExample: What is your favourite ice cream flavour?

word.entryDescription: to leave a place quickly in order to escape from something dangerous, frightening, unpleasant, etc
word.entryExample: The title of the news report was "Thousands flee civil war".

word.entryDescription: able to change or be changed easily according to the situation
word.entryExample: I have flexible working hours so I don't need to be at the office every day.

word.entryDescription: a journey by aircraft
word.entryExample: Airline prices can be competitive and night flights are generally cheaper.

word.entryDescription: not built or made well, and not providing much protection
word.entryExample: Eventually, the streets became narrower and the buildings became older, grander and less flimsy, and the traffic slowed to a single lane.

word.entryDescription: to move or stay on the surface of water or other liquid without sinking
word.entryExample: The houseboat floats smoothly down the river.

word.entryDescription: a large amount of water covering an area which is normally dry
word.entryExample: The floods are worse than expected.

word.entryDescription: a situation in which water from rivers or rain covers large areas of land
word.entryExample: The flooding is spreading across the region.

word.entryDescription: the flat surface you walk on inside a building
word.entryExample: There was a beautiful old carpet on the floor in the castle.

word.entryDescription: all plants that grow in a particular area
word.entryExample: I love the Cornish flora, especially the rainforest.

word.entryDescription: a powder made from grain, often wheat
word.entryExample: I'm going to make some biscuits so I need more flour.

word.entryDescription: to move in one direction steadily and continuously
word.entryExample: When energy flows, it moves in one direction, especially continuously and easily.
